objectives_timeline.value: Manage high-earner tax/benefit thresholds (keep taxable income under ~$150k) by increasing 401(k) and other tax-advantaged contributions while maintaining childcare benefits.
objectives_timeline.citation: CLIENT: I’d rather just keep my income below the $150,000 a year and keep the benefits that come with it.

objectives_timeline.value: Decide whether to contribute more to current workplace 401(k) vs consolidating into preferred provider (e.g., Vanguard Solo 401(k) or Traditional IRA) and eventually into a single, better-quality plan.
objectives_timeline.citation: CLIENT: But I’m kind of looking at do I put more on my employer’s pension or do I find a better fund?... I would like to keep all my funds Vanguard Solo 401(k), everything else combined into one 401(k), whether that be a Traditional IRA.

objectives_timeline.value: Develop an investment strategy to shift excess cash savings into longer-term investments while keeping an adequate emergency fund.
objectives_timeline.citation: CLIENT: ...it was mostly in cash because I was getting 5% interest on it... I’m trying to start investing a little bit more, but I’m trying to balance it, trying to keep about... ADVISOR: It would be good to start on the investment ladder.

objectives_timeline.value: Consider education savings (529 College Savings Plan or alternatives) for two young children without feeling overly locked in.
objectives_timeline.citation: ADVISOR: And you have 529? CLIENT: We don’t have a 529 at the moment. ... I’ve always been conscious of that because it locks the money away doesn’t it, into a 529.

objectives_timeline.value: Obtain professional review of existing 401(k) plans (BrightPath Workplace 401(k) and Vanguard Solo 401(k)) including fund choice, performance, and fees, and receive a holistic plan for pensions, brokerage account, and possible 529s.
objectives_timeline.citation: ADVISOR: So what I’m thinking is that so I’m going to send this to each 401(k) provider, get the information, come back to you and explain to you what you’ve got and what options you could have... brokerage account and maybe 529 College Savings Plan.

objectives_timeline.value: Address estate planning gaps (will and potentially marriage / legal protections) to protect partner and children.
objectives_timeline.citation: ADVISOR: Have you done a will? CLIENT: No I haven’t. ... ADVISOR: You should. Really? Very much for protection of your kids and your assets. Now, if something happened because you’re not married, it’s a different game.
